user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_calc_hash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_calc_hash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da, uint8_t *digest)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_MD5_finish (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_finish_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_finish_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    MHD_SHA512_256_finish (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* Should not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call itself does not directly invoke any <string.h> function, so the fragment as written does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A specific violation scenario would be if MHD_SHA256_finish internally uses a string.h function (for example memcpy) to write the SHA‑256 output (32 bytes) into the buffer pointed to by digest while the caller supplied a smaller buffer — e.g. digest was allocated as fewer than 32 bytes. In that case the internal memcpy/memmove would access beyond the bounds of digest and violate Rule 21.17.
